title: Grade 2 Activities
description: Building fluency with place value, operations, and measurement

level1.title: Numbers to 1000 & Place Value
level1.goal: Understand numbers to 1000, represent them in multiple ways, and compare and order numbers.

g2-l1-big-idea.title: Big idea
g2-l1-big-idea.content: In Grade 2, numbers grow to **1000**. Students learn that our number system is built on groups of ten: 10 ones = 1 ten, and 10 tens = 1 hundred. Understanding place value helps with comparing, ordering, and computing with bigger numbers.

g2-l1-notice.title: What to notice
g2-l1-notice.content:
* Can skip count by 5s, 10s, and 100s.
* Understands that 347 means 3 hundreds, 4 tens, and 7 ones.
* Can write numbers in expanded form (e.g., 500 + 20 + 3).
* Compares three-digit numbers by looking at hundreds first, then tens, then ones.
* Can locate numbers on a number line and estimate position.
* Rounds numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.

g2-l1-home.title: Try at home
g2-l1-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Build Big Numbers"**
  Use hundreds/tens/ones blocks (or draw them). Say a number like 362. Child builds it with 3 hundred-flats, 6 ten-rods, and 2 ones. Then say it as "3 hundreds, 6 tens, 2 ones."
* **Game B (second representation): "Number Line Jumps"**
  Draw a number line from 0 to 1000 (or use sections like 200–300). Pick numbers and find them on the line. Ask: "Is 673 closer to 600 or 700?"

g2-l1-videos.title: Optional videos
g2-l1-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * place value to 1000 for kids * skip counting by 5s 10s 100s * comparing three digit numbers for kids * rounding to nearest 10 and 100

level2.title: Addition & Subtraction Within 100
level2.goal: Build fluency adding and subtracting within 100 using models, mental strategies, and regrouping.

g2-l2-big-idea.title: Big idea
g2-l2-big-idea.content: In Grade 2, students add and subtract two-digit numbers fluently. They learn mental math strategies (like breaking numbers into tens and ones) and understand **regrouping** (trading 10 ones for 1 ten, or vice versa) using models like base-ten blocks.

g2-l2-notice.title: What to notice
g2-l2-notice.content:
* Can add/subtract within 100 using strategies like "add tens, then ones."
* Understands when to regroup: if ones add to 10 or more, make a new ten.
* Can show thinking with base-ten blocks or a number line.
* Uses estimation to check if an answer makes sense (47 + 36 is about 50 + 40 = 90).
* Solves word problems by identifying whether to add or subtract.

g2-l2-home.title: Try at home
g2-l2-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Base-Ten Addition"**
  Use blocks or draw tens and ones. For 48 + 27: show 4 tens 8 ones, then 2 tens 7 ones. Combine: 6 tens and 15 ones. Trade 10 ones for 1 ten → 7 tens 5 ones = 75.
* **Game B (second representation): "Number Line Hops"**
  For 63 − 28, start at 63, hop back 20 (to 43), then hop back 8 (to 35). Or count up from 28 to 63.

g2-l2-videos.title: Optional videos
g2-l2-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * adding two digit numbers with regrouping * subtracting two digit numbers with regrouping * make 100 mental math strategies * estimation and rounding grade 2

level3.title: Even/Odd, Equal Groups & Arrays
level3.goal: Notice patterns (even/odd) and build intuition for equal groups and arrays as repeated addition.

g2-l3-big-idea.title: Big idea
g2-l3-big-idea.content: Even numbers can be split into pairs with none left over. Arrays organize objects into equal rows and columns, helping students see **repeated addition** (e.g., 3 rows of 4 = 4+4+4). This is the foundation for multiplication in Grade 3.

g2-l3-notice.title: What to notice
g2-l3-notice.content:
* Can determine if a number is even or odd by pairing.
* Recognizes that even numbers end in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8.
* Can arrange objects into equal groups or rows.
* Uses skip counting (by 2s, 5s, 10s) to count arrays quickly.
* Understands that an array with 3 rows of 5 is the same as 5+5+5.

g2-l3-home.title: Try at home
g2-l3-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Pair It Up"**
  Grab a handful of objects (10–20). Try to pair them up. If there's one left over, it's odd. If all pair up, it's even.
* **Game B (second representation): "Build Arrays"**
  Use small objects (coins, blocks). Make an array: 4 rows of 3. Count: 3+3+3+3 = 12. Then flip it: 3 rows of 4. Still 12!

g2-l3-videos.title: Optional videos
g2-l3-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * even and odd numbers for kids * arrays and equal groups grade 2 * repeated addition with arrays * skip counting patterns for kids

level4.title: Measurement, Time, Money & Data
level4.goal: Measure length using standard units, tell time to 5 minutes, count coins, and read simple data displays.

g2-l4-big-idea.title: Big idea
g2-l4-big-idea.content: This level connects math to everyday life: measuring with rulers (inches and centimeters), telling time to 5 minutes, counting coins, and reading graphs. These skills help students see math as useful and practical.

g2-l4-notice.title: What to notice
g2-l4-notice.content:
* Can measure objects accurately with a ruler (aligning at zero).
* Compares lengths and finds differences (how much longer?).
* Tells time to the nearest 5 minutes and understands AM/PM.
* Counts mixed coins by starting with the largest values.
* Reads bar graphs and line plots to answer questions about data.

g2-l4-home.title: Try at home
g2-l4-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Measure Around the House"**
  Find 5 objects. Measure each in inches and centimeters. Compare: which is longest? How much longer?
* **Game B (second representation): "Coin Counting"**
  Give a mix of coins (quarters, dimes, nickels, pennies). Count together: start with quarters (25¢ each), then dimes, nickels, pennies. Reach a goal like 87¢.

g2-l4-videos.title: Optional videos
g2-l4-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * measuring with a ruler for kids * telling time to 5 minutes * counting coins for kids * reading bar graphs grade 2

level5.title: Shapes, Attributes & Equal Shares
level5.goal: Identify and describe shapes and partition shapes into equal shares (halves/thirds/fourths).

g2-l5-big-idea.title: Big idea
g2-l5-big-idea.content: Shapes have attributes: sides, vertices (corners), faces, edges. Students learn to describe and classify shapes by these features. They also split shapes into **equal parts** (halves, thirds, fourths), building the foundation for fractions.

g2-l5-notice.title: What to notice
g2-l5-notice.content:
* Can name and describe 2D shapes (triangle, quadrilateral, pentagon, hexagon) and 3D shapes (cube, sphere, cone, cylinder).
* Counts sides and vertices on 2D shapes; faces, edges, vertices on 3D shapes.
* Understands that equal shares must be the same size.
* Can partition a shape into halves, thirds, or fourths and identify fractions (e.g., "1 of 4 equal parts is one-fourth").

g2-l5-home.title: Try at home
g2-l5-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Shape Hunt"**
  Find shapes around the house. Count sides and corners. Is it a rectangle? A hexagon? A cylinder?
* **Game B (second representation): "Fair Sharing"**
  Cut a sandwich, pizza, or paper shape into equal parts. Share with 2, 3, or 4 people. Talk about halves, thirds, fourths. Are the parts equal?

g2-l5-videos.title: Optional videos
g2-l5-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * 2D and 3D shapes for kids * shape attributes sides vertices * equal shares halves thirds fourths * partitioning shapes into fractions grade 2
